pulltitle: fix(client): remove redundant metrics context data
pullsbody:
Fixes #216.

The flow data is modelled as `flow_event` and `flow_metadata` tables in redshift, which are joined on `flowId`. All of the interesting properties are stored in `flow_metadata`, so we don't actually need to pass them round everywhere and emit them from every event. As long as they are present on the begin event, which they are as of mozilla/fxa-content-server#4234, the import scripts will populate the `flow_metadata` table correctly.

This change stops sending most of those properties to endpoints that accept metrics context data. We still need to send `flowId` and `flowBeginTime`.

Fixes #216.

The flow data is modelled as `flow_event` and `flow_metadata` tables in redshift, which are joined on `flowId`. All of the interesting properties are stored in `flow_metadata`, so we don't actually need to pass them round everywhere and emit them from every event. As long as they are present on the begin event, which they are as of mozilla/fxa-content-server#4234, the import scripts will populate the `flow_metadata` table correctly.

This change stops sending most of those properties to endpoints that accept metrics context data. We still need to send `flowId` and `flowBeginTime`.

Marking this as `WIP` for now because failing tests. 😕

pulltitle: Eliminate redundant payload data
pullsbody:
There are two changes here, both related to the discussion in https://github.com/mozilla/fxa-auth-server/issues/1345:
1. A `service` option is added to `certificateSign`, which adds a `service` parameter to the query string. This enables us to properly fix the issue of spurious placeholder devices discussed in https://github.com/mozilla/fxa-content-server/issues/3933.
2. The `metricsContext` option is removed from `accountReset` and `certificateSign`, as they're about to be removed from the auth server for https://github.com/mozilla/fxa-auth-server/issues/1345. I've verified that the content server never passes it to those methods and nor should other clients be doing that.

@shane-tomlinson, low-priority r?

pullsbody:
As mentioned in #80 and dicussed a bit on IRC, a review of the approach taken would be appreciated. the amd-loader.js bit is a little bit wacky, but seems to work reasonably well.
- No longer runs bower on npm install
- Added "setup" task for development seutp
- Added basic AMD shim
- Exposed FxAccountClient via AMD shim as node-style module
- Declared runtime dependencies in package.json
- Explicitly specified "files" for small npm upload/download

There's a slight issue that due to https://github.com/bitwiseshiftleft/sjcl/issues/160 running the module produces an error to console:

```
There was an error collecting entropy from the browser:
{ toString: [Function],
  message: 'random: addEntropy only supports number, array of numbers or string' }
```

I tried this out against a local npm registry, here's what this enables:

```
> npm publish --registry http://localhost:5984
npm http PUT http://localhost:5984/fxa-js-client
npm http 200 http://localhost:5984/fxa-js-client
+ fxa-js-client@0.1.11
```

```
> tar tf fxa-js-client-0.1.11.tgz
package/package.json
package/README.md
package/LICENSE
package/client/FxAccountClient.js
package/client/.jshintrc
package/client/lib/credentials.js
package/client/lib/errors.js
package/client/lib/hawk.js
package/client/lib/hawkCredentials.js
package/client/lib/hkdf.js
package/client/lib/pbkdf2.js
package/client/lib/request.js
package/client/node/amd-loader.js
package/client/node/index.js

```
> npm install fxa-js-client --registry http://localhost:5984

Simple logger that reports timing metrics for each grunt task. This can help us track if certain tasks start taking longer times to complete.

```
Done, without errors.

Elapsed time
loading tasks    257ms
jshint:config    32ms
requirejs:prod   291ms
requirejs:debug  36ms
bytesize:all     9ms
Total            625ms
```
